data.text: Wisdom lifteth up the head of him that is of low degree,
Commend not a man for his beauty;
The bee is little among such as fly;
Boast not of thy clothing and raiment,
Many kings have sat down upon the ground;
Many mighty men have been greatly disgraced;
Blame not before thou hast examined the truth:
Answer not before thou hast heard the cause:
Strive not in a matter that concerneth thee not;
My son, meddle not with many matters:
There is one that laboreth, and taketh pains, and maketh haste,
Again, there is another that is slow, and hath need of help,
And lifted up his head from misery;
Prosperity and adversity, life and death,
The gift of the Lord remaineth with the godly,
There is that waxeth rich by his wariness and pinching,
Whereas he saith, I have found rest,
Be steadfast in thy covenant, and be conversant therein,
Marvel not at the works of sinners;
The blessing of the Lord is in the reward of the godly,
Say not, What profit is there of my service?
Again, say not, I have enough, and possess many things,
In the day of prosperity there is a forgetfulness of affliction:
For it is an easy thing unto the Lord in the day of death
The affliction of an hour maketh a man forget pleasure:
Judge none blessed before his death:
Bring not every man into thy house:
Like as a partridge taken and kept in a cage, so is the heart of the proud:
For he lieth in wait, and turneth good into evil,
Of a spark of fire a heap of coals is kindled:
Take heed of a mischievous man, for he worketh wickedness:
Receive a stranger into thy house, and he will disturb thee,
